{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3703866,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T12:50:06.782Z","cooked":"

I wanted to walk through the derivation of the various mechanism equations we encounter in FRC (motor, gearbox, elevator, etc). I know that these are derived in Controls Engineering and this work was really helpful in collecting my thoughts.

This is by no means a professional document. More a set of notes.

I didn’t do anything significantly different compared to Controls engineering. I may have used a slightly different name for a variable or walked through the math in a different way. The only big thing was not redefining Kt and Kv based on number of motors and gearing (This is done in WPILib’s DCMotor class, BTW).

This is a work in progress. I’d like some feedback (or math corrections .

Also this let me flex my markdown and Latex skills.

Enjoy!

FRC Mechanism Derivations

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T12:50:06.782Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":322,"readers_count":321,"score":214.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505017,"topic_slug":"personal-derivations","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/narmstro2020/FRC-Mechanism-Derivations","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - narmstro2020/FRC-Mechanism-Derivations","clicks":71},{"url":"https://file.tavsys.net/control/controls-engineering-in-frc.pdf","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":23}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/personal-derivations/505017/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3704009,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T18:30:40.966Z","cooked":"

Do watch out for the frame of reference and make sure that they are documented. These derivations are a bit hard to follow because they weren’t documented well and I had to assume the frame of reference of the mechanical terms. Making sure you know what’s in the mechanisms frame of reference and the motor’s frame of reference matters a ton because they both get used frequently, and people often make errors due to incorrectly accounting for the frame of reference. For example, the dry friction term should be dry friction from the motor in the motor’s frame of reference, not just dry friction, as it could be referenced at either the motor’s or the mechanism’s frame.

For you angular to linear derivation, you need to account for the inertia of the rotating system as this is usually much larger than the mass of the linear system you are working with. For some 15kg robots I am working on, they effectively weigh 39kg more than what a scale would say due to the motor MOI. For mechanisms with high gear ratios, the motors MOI is at least an order of magnitude more important than the mechanism’s MOI due to how gearboxes scale inertia.

You will also probably want to include the viscous damping term separately, as this is mechanism dependent and strongly dependent on the gearbox. Planetary gearboxes especially have a lot of viscous damping and this is generally a quite accurate way to characterize their losses.

Thank you. To be fair Wheel is currently a work in progress.

In terms of frame of reference I thought I did a good job indicating them with the subscripts? Also are you referring to dry friction as static friction. If you can offer an example to handle frame of reference better that would be appreciated.

On the MOI of the motors: I agree. I hadn’t thought about that too much. I will address. A gearbox as a bare motor would have a generally tiny MOI. Am I correct in understanding this as the effect of the motor’s MOI is scaled due to the gearing even when incredibly tiny on its own.

Viscous damping is directly proportional to the velocity right? Also referred to as sliding friction.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T19:00:12.667Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":136,"readers_count":135,"score":32.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505017,"topic_slug":"personal-derivations","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50219,"username":"Alex_Y","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/personal-derivations/505017/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3704034,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T19:25:54.378Z","cooked":"
narmstro:

On the MOI of the motors: I agree. I hadn’t thought about that too much. I will address. A gearbox as a bare motor would have a generally tiny MOI. Am I correct in understanding this as the effect of the motor’s MOI is scaled due to the gearing even when incredibly tiny on its own.

Yes, inertia is scaled by the gear ratio squared, which is usually bigger than the motor’s MOI is small. In the mechanisms’s frame of reference, the motor inertia is increased by this term, and in the motor’s frame of reference, the mechanism’s MOI is decreased by this term.

narmstro:

In terms of frame of reference I thought I did a good job indicating them with the subscripts? Also are you referring to dry friction as static friction. If you can offer an example to handle frame of reference better that would be appreciated.

Subscripts alone aren’t a good way to handle frames of reference. You can define the dry friction in the motor’s frame of reference, but you can also define it in the mechanism’s frame of reference, which is sometimes easier to work with. You can use them if you also explicitly define the reference frame when you define the variables, but when you define your variables, you only define the units without the frame of reference.

narmstro:

Viscous damping is directly proportional to the velocity right? Also referred to as sliding friction.

Yes no. Sliding friction is the dry friction term you get when the object is moving (you generally don’t want to use static friction because your mechanisms is generally always moving when you care about its performance). Viscous damping (also sometimes known as wet friction, drag…) comes from fluid interactions and you can get significant amounts of it from bearing or gearbox grease, especially high-speed bearings and gearboxes,

When I make the transition from motor to gearbox, the moment of inertia I use in the equations is assumed to be the total moment of inertia of the gearbox system, motors, gearing, etc.
